document-info.title: Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement with Magnifying Glass

section.title: Variables
section.content: Variables Scale of measurement Nominal Ordinal Interval Ratio Variables Scale of measurement Nominal Ordinal Interval Ratio
section.related-content:
In the previous section, a simple distinction was made between quantitative and categorical variables. However, there is a more precise method of categorizing variables: it is called scale of measurement. The scales of measurement become increasingly precise with each level, while retaining the characteristics of the level below it. For instance, ordinal data builds on the characteristics of nominal level data and, therefore, is more precise than it.
Now we are going to take a closer look at the characteristics of these 4 levels of measurement

section.content: Nominal Variables Differences Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Nominal Variables Differences Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content:
The first level of measurement is nominal. It is the least precise measure of data as it only indicates differences. Nominal level
 data uses discrete categories to describe qualitative differences.

section.content: Example of a Nominal Variable Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Types of Pets Birds Fish Cats Dogs Example of a Nominal Variable Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Types of Pets Birds Fish Cats Dogs
section.related-content: An example of a nominal variable is types of pets. For instance, types of pets could include birds, fish, cats, and dogs. None of the categories (in this case, types of pets) is implicitly better than the other. Rather, the categories reflect different types of pets.

section.content: Other Examples of Nominal Variables Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Gender (Male, Female, Transgender) Eye color (Blue, Green, Brown, Hazel) Type of house (Bungalow, Duplex, Ranch) Type of resident (homeowner, renter) Other Examples of Nominal Variables Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Gender (Male, Female, Transgender) Eye color (Blue, Green, Brown, Hazel) Type of house (Bungalow, Duplex, Ranch) Type of resident (homeowner, renter)
section.related-content:
Other examples of nominal variables include:
Gender
Eye color
Type of house and
Type of resident
The categories for each of these nominal variables reflect qualitative differences.

section.content: Ordinal Variables Ordered Differences Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Ordinal Variables Ordered Differences Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content:
Now let’s take a closer look at Ordinal Variables
The second level of measurement is ordinal. Ordinal level data is more precise than nominal data as the differences can now be ranked ordered; however, it does not indicate that the differences between two numbers are fixed or equal.

section.content: Example of Ordinal Variable An ordinal variable is a categorical variable for which the possible values are ordered. Ordinal variables can be considered “in between” categorical and quantitative variables. Order of Finishes in a Race 1st Place 2nd Place Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Example of Ordinal Variable An ordinal variable is a categorical variable for which the possible values are ordered. Ordinal variables can be considered “in between” categorical and quantitative variables. Order of Finishes in a Race 1st Place 2nd Place Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content:
An example of an ordinal variable is the order of finishes in a race. For instance, we can say that Tanesha finished first and
Alexis finished second; however, we do not know the degree of difference. It could be that Tanesha won by 2 seconds or 20 minutes.

section.content:
Educational level:
 1: Elementary school education
 2: High school graduate
 3: Some college
 4: College graduate
 5: Graduate degree Survey Question Responses: “My general health is……..” 1: Poor
 2: Reasonable
 3: Good
 4: Excellent Other Examples of Ordinal Variables Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Educational level:
 1: Elementary school education
 2: High school graduate
 3: Some college
 4: College graduate
 5: Graduate degree Survey Question Responses: “My general health is……..” 1: Poor
 2: Reasonable
 3: Good
 4: Excellent Other Examples of Ordinal Variables Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content:
Other examples of ordinal variables include:
Educational Level and
Some Survey Question responses
The categories for each of these ordinal variables show order, but not the magnitude of difference between two adjacent points.

section.content: Interval Variables Ordered Differences with Equal Intervals Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Interval Variables Ordered Differences with Equal Intervals Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content: The third level of measurement is interval. It builds upon the characteristics of ordinal data through the addition of meaningful differences between two numbers. That is, the distance between pairs of consecutive numbers is assumed to be equal. However, interval variables do not have a meaningful zero point. Thus, a zero does not mean the absence of the attribute, but rather is a particular (but arbitrary) point on the scale.

section.content: Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Temperature in Celsius Example of Interval Variable Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Temperature in Celsius Example of Interval Variable
section.related-content: For instance, when temperature is measured in Celsius, the one degree difference between 35 degrees and 36 degrees, is assumed to be the same as the one degree difference between 25 degrees and 26 degrees. However, zero degrees in Celsius does not mean the absence of heat, since there are below freezing temperatures, such as 20 below. The same characteristics also hold true for temperature measured in Fahrenheit.

section.content: Other Examples of Interval Variables IQ Scores SAT Scores Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Other Examples of Interval Variables IQ Scores SAT Scores Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content:
Other examples of interval variables include:
IQ Scores and
SAT Scores
For each of these interval variables, the distance between pairs of consecutive numbers is assumed to be equal, but they do not have a meaningful zero point.

section.content: Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Ratio Variables Ordered Differences with Equal Intervals and Meaningful Zero Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Ratio Variables Ordered Differences with Equal Intervals and Meaningful Zero Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content: The fourth and final level of measurement is ratio. It has all the characteristics of interval data plus a meaningful zero point.

section.content: Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content: A good example of ratio level data is age.  For instance, we know that someone, who is 40 years old, is twice as old as someone, who is 20 years old. There is also a meaningful zero point; that is, it is possible to have the absence of age.

section.content: Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Other Examples of Ratio Variables Height Weight Cost of a Car, in Dollars Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Other Examples of Ratio Variables Height Weight Cost of a Car, in Dollars
section.related-content:
Other examples of ratio variables include:
Height
Weight
Cost of a Car, in Dollars
For each of these ratio variables, the distance between pairs of consecutive numbers is assumed to be equal and there is a meaningful zero point.

section.content: Changed from Most Precise Level of Measurement to a Less Precise Level of Measurement Age in Years (ex. 3 years, 10 years) is Ratio Level Age Groups (ex. Toddler, Adolescent, Young adulthood, Middle Age) is Ordinal Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Changed from Most Precise Level of Measurement to a Less Precise Level of Measurement Age in Years (ex. 3 years, 10 years) is Ratio Level Age Groups (ex. Toddler, Adolescent, Young adulthood, Middle Age) is Ordinal Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content: It is important to note that more precise data can always be scaled down to less precise data. For instance, a ratio level variable like age can be scaled down into a ordinal variable of age groups, including  toddler, adolescent, young adulthood, and middle age.

section.content: Age Groups (ex. Toddler, Adolescent, Middle Age) cannot be changed into Years (ex. 3 years, 10 years) Cannot change a less precise level of measurement into a more precise level of measurement Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement Age Groups (ex. Toddler, Adolescent, Middle Age) cannot be changed into Years (ex. 3 years, 10 years) Cannot change a less precise level of measurement into a more precise level of measurement Characteristics of the Different Scales of Measurement
section.related-content: Less precise data, however, cannot be made into more precise data. That is, an ordinal level variable, like age groups, cannot be changed into a ratio level variable, such as age in years.

section.content: + Final Thoughts about Scale of Measurement + Final Thoughts about Scale of Measurement
section.related-content:
So, why is it important understand scale of measurement?
Statistical methods are ways of summarizing analyzing and interpreting data, and are designed for specific types of data. Researchers need to know the level of measurement of their data when selecting a statistical method since using an incorrect method for analyzing data can affect the reliability and accuracy of the results.
Be sure to keep these levels of measurement in mind whenever you are planning to analyze data.
